rComments: the worst

Lot of hate here. The class is pretty straight forward if you can just follow the book. If you go to class and pay attention, you should be fine.  You auto-fail if you don't pass the programming portion of the class. I was late on 2 assignments and he gave me time over the summer to fix and regrade. He DOES care and it save my grade. (got an A)

The assignments are not hard, but the main problem at this class is that the requirements for the programming assignment are very unclear. Thus, your program can work, but you will have 50% of grade. I think, a lot of students got the programs from their friends who took this class with this professor before and they fixed the mistakes.

Assignments and lectures are disorganized. GET THE BOOK. As others have said, he DOES care a lot about students. You just have to reach out. One of my assignments had a tiny bug which caused me to fail the programming section which prevented me form passing the class. He let me fix it over the summer and I ended up with an A.

Van Gelder does not specify anything in terms of assignments or tests. Very disorganized. Lectures are him rambling about topics that are not essential for future classes and does not value lecture time.  Worst professor I have ever had.

Van Gelder is probably one of the worst professors I've had. Most of what I learned in his class was either taught to me by other students that had previously learned the material, or through the text book. He graded all of our programs via a script that didn't work and probably more than a third of the class got an incomplete, due to the script.

Is a tough grader without telling you what he wants from you. His test are easy, but he will throw random stuff that he never brings up, stuff that has noting to do with Algorithms, such as unix commands... Did not cover essential materials such as redblack trees. Overall a very boring, unorganized, and grumpy professor.

I found the overall structure of the class conducive to learning the material, though his lectures could be more organized.  Programs complement current class topics and exams are fair. More than enough resources are extended for students to do well in this class, and AVG is attentive to student needsresponsive to questions if you reach out.
Lectures are hard to understand. The book isn't much better. Fortunately, the homework and tests are reasonable.

While his lectures are slightly unclear and he has a bit of tendency to ramble, I have not yet met a professor who cares as much about his students as Allen Van Gelder. His assignments are effective at teaching the material, and he is willing to spend a great deal of time helping students outside of standard hours. Good professor, and great person.

Absolutely terrible. Focuses only on programming with hardly any theory. We hardly touched on proofs at all. If you need to take 102 as well, this class will screw you. Take this with Tantalo or Helmbold instead.
Avoid if possible. AVG is an ancient thing that should have retired years ago. Lectures are messy and unorganized, and the textbook (which he co-authored) reflects that.
The worst professor I've ever had. During the one hour lecture he talked and rarely taught. Avoid him.
best bad professor ever lol

Your classmates will complain about his teaching style, but seriously, his lectures should be treated as supplements to the class, meaning you should not rely solely on lecture to learn the material. The tests and programming assignments are easy if you prepare for them. If you need to get your CS101 req out of the way, this guy will be the easiest

First red flag - another professor who makes you use the book he wrote. Fortunately his lectures are the oral version of the text, except less clear. This means that you can avoid going to his dry lectures where he is openly rude to students by staying home and reading the text. Didn't cover induction because  - his words - "I hate induction."

He is an okay teacher. Not good at lecturing but you do learn stuff from him. Tests are exactly the same as old tests (if you can get your hands on them) and programming assignments build on each other. I was lucky to have 2 good TA's for this class or else I would have failed the programming part.

His book is essential, cause the code for your programming assignments comes straight out of it. Lectures are piecemeal and scattered. I know people who got close to 100% on programming assignments and did not pass the programming requirement; the requirements are vague. Ask him to spell out the requirements to pass at the very beginning.
Lacks any sort of clarity, jumps to an answer with no explanation, and is extremely unorganized.  The only reason I like him is because he gives really easy assignments.

NEVER TAKE A CLASS WITH HIM. His lectures are very dry and boring and his passing requirements are arbitrary. I had an 97% average on my programming assignments and that was not considered 'satisfactory' and I still had to redo them in order to pass the class.

Well, he's retiring what I heard. XD, but he is the slowest lecturer ever, barely covers induction, and gives you pretty easy programs if you passed 12b. Cons: Never gets to red-black trees, teaches from his bk badly, assignments build on each other, can't stay organized if his life depended on it- dare ya to look in his office...

Professor Van Gelder chose to demonstrate more cookie cutter type data structures and skip over the interesting ones such as Red-Black Trees.  He also decided to skip over proofs, because "we wouldn't do them correctly." I wish we could have practiced in this course, 102 required proof techniques that should have been covered here.

Worst teacher I ever had. Fails students based of small technicalities that he doesn't even explain. Can't code for his life, and makes the students use his code. Shouldn't teach.  NEVER TAKE A CLASS WITH HIM.

Holy moly have I never had a worse teacher. He teach from his own textbook which doesn't help when I can't even understand what he's talking about. His java code is awful and he expects us to not only modify it, but convert it to C (which I was better off just rewriting from scratch). The labs build on eachother and you must pass them or fail the c

He will not give students a straight answer about anything. Required in person grading for programming assignments, which is humiliating and time consuming. You have to pass the programming portion of his class, which is 4 assignments that build off one another. Does not tell you this, of course. Very rude to students who ask questions. Stay away.

Incoherent lectures; homework was pushed back several times because he didn't cover the material. No people skills; personality is like a wall. I was so excited to take this class as a CS major (had my Cormen book ready), then found out who I was dealing with and we were using his book. The book was confusing and of no help at all.

Incompetent.  Teaches from his own text. He often forgets the solution to an example 30 minutes into the discussion.  Disjointed lectures. Graded the first exam too hard and failed half the class.  He did give a re-exam to improve our marks, though it was obviously his fault.  He's an angry, old, cranky man without use or kindness.  Tenure is bad.

His lectures tended towards rambling. He didn't really prepare for each lecture so it is common for him to get 5 minutes into an example, get confused, and start over or change previous parts of it to suit the end result he was going for. The key to this class is study the practice tests a lot and go to TA hours. Our TA was amazing and saved us.

He's hard of hearing, difficult to understand, and a poor professor. I knew how to use UNIX before, but I really disappointed how he went with the course. HISTORY? Unix history is useless. I felt the class was most serious when he forced everyone to learn C-shell scripting by themselves. But if you need an easy GE course, take this with Pass/fail.

Ummm, not my most favorite class in the world, but overall CS 101 was a great learning experience. I went to most of the labs and sections as resources to learn outside of class. His book sort of stinks because it's very verbose and doesn't get straight to the point. Test were very easy if you practiced them or knew what was going to be on it.

Allen Van Gelder is very confusing. I learned most of the material by reading the book (not his book but Cormen's). He is very condescending towards students, and acts condescending when others point out errors in his proofs. He expects each proof to be done exactly how he would do it. He is not open to new ideas from his students.

If you want to kill any passion you may have for algorithms go to his class.His exams are a test of how well you crammed the sample exam.There is a certain meanness in his grading.I believe he knows a lot but I suspect he is just not intrested in teaching.I think the whole excercise is equally painful to him as it is to the students.

I hated this class with a passion, I got lucky with a grade of a B. Do his programs they are easy and his midterms are not bad but his lectures suck major ass. Go to thib sections if he is still around. All this bad mouthing is coming from a CE major, so CS major might have more fun with this class

I this class or maybe it is the way the professor presented. If Thib is there go to his MSI, you won't be dissappointed. His lectures suck and don't think there is a lesson plan plus you have to use his crappy book that is made for grad students.
Van Gelder is your enemy.  I excelled in his class, but he clearly tries to insult and injure the other students with irregularly (and meaninglessly) difficult grading standards.  Avoid at all costs.
Terrible lecturer, even worse tutor.  Office hours and sections were painful.  Every once in a LONG while showed a glimmer of compassion for struggling students.  No people skills whatsoever.

Totally clueless in class.  Teaches things at random and jumps around.  Also, no solution to anything are ever posted seeing as how "it's against class policy to post solutions."  Stay away from this one if you can.

I showed up for his office hours TWICE, and he was not there!  Dude needs to get some lesson plans too - lectures had no structure and were vague.  Definately a case against tenure.  Thank god for Thib, our MSI TA, who saved the entire class from completely failing.

He showed no interest in teaching the class.  His lectures are not very useful.  He bases his tests from the topics he addressed in class but the materials stated in the book.  His practice tests are wonderful. ;)  All in all he is a much better choice than Tantalo (the other option).

Clueless. Teaches from his own text which is essentially worthless. Needs to learn definition of lesson plan. No programing assignments for first half of class and then two programs due every week for the second half, in java and then the second program is the translation from java to c.
